situations.text: Should the minimum age to obtain a learner’s permit be increased from 16 years to 18 years to improve road safety?

options: Yes; as at 16 years of age individuals lack the experience and confidence to drive safely
Yes; as the majority of road accidents involves a driver who has had less than 2 years of driving experience
No; as learners often have an adult supervisor so they do pose a minimal risk to the safety of other road users
No; as being older does not necessarily mean that an individual will make a safer driver, experience is more likely to dictate a driver’s proficiency
questions.explanation: A and B have a fundamental flaw in their argument – failing to make the distinction between age and experience. Just because an individual is older when they start driving, it doesn’t mean that they are more experienced

situations.text: Should violent video games be banned due to their contribution to violence amongst youths?

options: Yes; as all children who play violent video games are far more likely to engage in bullying, fighting and other forms of aggression
Yes; as the addictive nature of violent video games means that some children are playing these games instead of doing more productive things - like homework, exercise and socialising

No; recently, sales of violent video games have significantly increased while violent juvenile crime rates have significantly decreased, so no correlation between violent video games and violence amongst youths has yet been proven
No; rates of violence amongst youths should be reduced through counselling, education, rehabilitation and other forms of constructive outreach
questions.explanation: Only A and C address the issue of violence and how video games contribute to this and A is a generalisation

situations.text: Should all members of the community be vaccinated to prevent the spread of diseases?

options: Yes; as they provide a level of immunity to all individuals vaccinated
Yes; as they both provide immunity to the individual and prevent diseases establishing a foothold in the community
No; as individuals should be entitled to choose whether (or not) to be vaccinated
No; as not all members of the community can be vaccinated (including the immunocompromised) and studies have shown that a 100% vaccination rate is not required to eliminate diseases
questions.explanation: The question stresses the notion of all members of the community being vaccinated and only D logically and rationally points out the lack of feasibility of this

situations.text: Should genetically modified crops be grown to address world hunger?

options: Yes; as genetically modified crops can thrive in the harshest of conditions, lower the price of food globally and increase nutritional content to help alleviate world hunger
Yes; as genetically modified crops have been proven safe to consume through numerous tests and trials
No; as human clinical trials have not yet been conducted on genetically modified crops
No; as genetically modified crops tend to be more resistant than standard crops, they may be able to outcompete such crops and ultimately trigger detrimental changes to the global food supply
questions.explanation: Only A and D address the notion of world hunger and D is a jump in logic that is unsubstantiated and not properly explained

situations.text: Should tablets be used in schools to aid student learning?

options: Yes; as many textbooks can be stored on one device, tablets provide a more convenient, efficient alternative to paperback books
Yes; as there are many educational apps that can be downloaded on tablets
No; not only are tablets often very expensive, but they also cause a range of health problems (such as blurred vision, eyestrain and headaches)
No; while educational apps can be downloaded on tablets, tablets have many distractions (including games and social media) that may impede students’ learning and concentration
questions.explanation: Only B and D address the notion of student learning and B does not establish a strong enough link between educational apps and student learning

situations.text: Should a tax on sugary drinks be introduced to reduce the rates of obesity and other associated diseases?

options: Yes; as excessive sugar consumption has been proven to contribute to obesity
Yes; as the tax will disincentivise individuals from purchasing sugary drinks, potentially reducing consumption of such beverages - which are known to contribute to obesity
No; as obesity is caused by a number of factors, including exercise and lifestyle rather than sugar alone
No; as those who can afford to pay the extra tax on sugary drinks will not be disincentivised from consuming them whatsoever
questions.explanation: Only B links sugar consumption to obesity and evaluates the potential impacts of a sugar tax on this

situations.text:
The term 'Britain' is used both as a synonym for Great Britain, and as a synonym for the United Kingdom. Usage is mixed: the UK Government prefers to use the term 'UK' rather than 'Britain' or 'British' on its own website (except when referring to embassies). The UK Permanent Committee on Geographical Names recognises 'United Kingdom' and 'UK or U.K.' as shortened and abbreviated geopolitical terms for the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland in its toponymic guidelines; it does not list 'Britain' but notes 'it is only the one specific nominal term 'Great Britain' which invariably excludes Northern Ireland.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: The UK government refers to its own embassies under the term UK
The UK Permanent Committee on Geographical Names chooses the names of things in the UK
The term ‘Britain’ is used more than the term ‘UK’
The term ‘Great Britain’ is not used as it does not include Northern Ireland
The term ‘United Kingdom’ includes Ireland
questions.explanation:
1. The UK government uses the term “Britain” or “British” on its own website, as indicated where it states that the government prefers to use the term UK over Britain or British, except when referring to embassies. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We can’t tell for sure whether the UK Permanent Committee on Geographical Names chooses the names of things in the UK as all we know is that it recognises the United Kingdom and UK as shortened terms for the full geographical name. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We cannot conclude that the term Britain is used more than UK purely based on this information alone. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We know that ‘Great Britain’ excluded Northern Ireland, however we do not know that this is the reason the term Great Britain is not used. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. The term United Kingdom is short for the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, however we do not know if Ireland is included in this name or not (or if it is just Northern Ireland that is included). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
The Constitution of the United Kingdom is uncodified and consists mostly of a collection of disparate written sources, including statutes, judge-made case law and international treaties, together with constitutional conventions. As there is no technical difference between ordinary statutes and 'constitutional law', the UK Parliament can perform 'constitutional reform' simply by passing Acts of Parliament, and thus has the political power to change or abolish almost any written or unwritten element of the constitution. No Parliament can pass laws that future Parliaments cannot change.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: The Constitution of the United Kingdom is a single document
There are no differences whatsoever between constitutional law and ordinary statutes
Acts of Parliament can be passed in the same way as ordinary statutes
The UK Parliament can change aspects of the UK’s Constitution
A future parliament in the UK can always change past laws
questions.explanation:
1. It states that the Constitution of the United Kingdom consists of a collection of disparate written sources, so it is not one document. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We only know that there is no technical difference between the two, but we do not know that there are no differences whatsoever. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We cannot tell that they are passed in the same way as we have no information about how either the Acts of Parliament or ordinary statutes are passed. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. It states that the UK Parliament can perform constitutional reform and has the political power to change or abolish almost any written or unwritten element of the constitution. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. It states that no parliament can pass laws that future parliaments cannot change. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
The position of prime minister, the UK's head of government, belongs to the person most likely to command the confidence of the House of Commons; this individual is typically the leader of the political party or coalition of parties that holds the largest number of seats in that chamber. The prime minister chooses a cabinet and its members are formally appointed by the monarch to form Her Majesty's Government. By convention, the monarch respects the prime minister's decisions of government.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: The Prime Minister of the UK is elected by the population
The monarch of the UK chooses the cabinet members
It is uncommon for the monarch to change the composition of the proposed cabinet members
The UK Parliament is also known as Her Majesty’s Government
There can be situations where the Prime Minister does not lead the party with the greatest number of parliamentary seats
questions.explanation:
1. We do not know how the prime minister is elected. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We only know that the prime minister chooses members of cabinet, so we do not know if the monarch has any influence in regards to that or not. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. It states that by convention, the monarch respects the prime minister’s decisions of government, which implies that usually the monarch does not interfere with the prime minister’s cabinet choices as well. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. The UK Parliament is not mentioned in the passage so we cannot make this conclusion. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. It states that the prime minister is typically the leader of the political party or coalition of parties that holds the largest number of seats in that chamber, however as it uses the word ‘typically’, it is implied that there are situations where the prime minister can lead the party that does not have the greatest number of parliamentary seats. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Wind farms, which are arrays of large turbines, are becoming an increasingly important source of intermittent renewable energy and are used by many countries as part of a strategy to reduce their reliance on fossil fuels. One assessment claimed that, as of 2009, wind had the 'lowest relative greenhouse gas emissions, the least water consumption demands and... the most favourable social impacts' compared to photovoltaic, hydro, geothermal, coal and gas.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recycling

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Wind farms have the lowest greenhouse gas emissions of any energy source
Any large collection of large turbines is known as a wind farm
Geothermal energy production uses up more water than wind farms
Energy produced from coal produces more greenhouse gas emissions than the energy generated from hydro
Wind farms are being used by some countries to help move away from fossil fuels
questions.explanation:
. The passage only states that wind farms have the lowest relative greenhouse gas emissions compared to photovoltaic, hydro, geothermal, coal and gas energy, so we cannot say that it has the lowest greenhouse gas emissions of any energy source. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. A wind farm is an array of large turbines, however we do not know that any large collection of large turbines is known as a wind farm (ie. we do not know the all collections or arrays of large turbines are known as wind farms). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. Since wind farms have the least water consumption demands compared to photovoltaic, hydro, geothermal, coal and gas energy, we can conclude that geothermal energy uses more water than wind farms. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. We do not have any information comparing hydro to coal energy. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Wind farms are used by many countries as part of a strategy to reduce their reliance on fossil fuels. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
In the strictest sense, recycling of a material would produce a fresh supply of the same material. This is accomplished when recycling certain types of materials, such as metal cans, which can become a can again and again, indefinitely, without losing purity in the product. However, this is often difficult or too expensive, so 'recycling' of many products or materials involves their reuse in producing different materials (for example, paperboard) instead.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recycling

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: If a paper is recycled, it can only be remade into paper again
Reusing certain materials for producing new materials can be classified as recycling
Recycling metal cans as metal cans again is too expensive to do
The recycling of products through reusing them to produce different things result in the original product losing its purity
Theoretically, one metal can be recycled forever
questions.explanation:
1. Theoretically, recycling follows this process, however as stated in the passage recycling of many products involves their reuse in producing different materials. Thus, if a paper is recycled it could become any number of different things. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. Since recycling of many products involves their reuse in producing different materials, we can infer that reusing materials to create different materials can be classified as recycling. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. The passage states that recycling in the strictest sense, producing a fresh supply of the same material, is too difficult or expensive. Thus recycling metal cans as metal cans again can be too expensive, but it could also be too difficult so we can’t be sure that it is too expensive for sure. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We cannot draw any conclusions about the relative purity of recycling products through reusing them to produce different things (we only know that recycling materials into the same materials does not lose purity). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Theoretically, if a can were to be recycled, it would produce a fresh supply of the same material without losing any purity, which means 100% of the material is reused to create a new can every time. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Historically, indigenous British people were thought to be descended from the various ethnic groups that settled there before the 12th century: the Celts, Romans, Anglo-Saxons, Norse and the Normans. Welsh people could be the oldest ethnic group in the UK. A 2006 genetic study shows that more than 50 per cent of England's gene pool contains Germanic Y chromosomes. Another 2005 genetic analysis indicates that 'about 75 per cent of the traceable ancestors of the modern British population had arrived in the British isles by about 6,200 years ago, at the start of the British Neolithic or Stone Age'.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Celts, Romans, Anglo-Saxons, Norse and Normans were the only ethnic groups to settle in Britain before the 12th century
Welsh people existed in Britain before the 12th century
Some ancestors of people in England were from Germany
The British Neolithic Age occurred before the 12th century
Genetic analyses can be used to trace a person’s ancestry
questions.explanation:
1. Based on the information in the passage, we cannot be certain that these were the only ethnic groups settled at the time that we know of. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We know Welsh people were the oldest ethnic group in the UK, but we do not know if they were the oldest ethnic group in Britain (Britain and the UK are not the same thing). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We know that 50% of England’s gene pool contains Germanic Y chromosomes, but we cannot use this information to say that some ancestors of people in England were from Germany (how do we know that these Germanic chromosomes came from Germany, or Germany as it is known now?). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. The start of the British Neolithic age was 6,200 years ago, while the 12th century was only around 8-9 centuries ago (800-900 years), at least nowhere near 6,200 years ago. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. It states that another 2005 genetic analysis indicates that about 75% of the traceable ancestors of the modern British population had arrived in the British Isles by about 6,200 years ago – thus we can infer that genetic analyses can determine some traceable ancestors. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
The term 'penicillin' was used originally for benzylpenicillin, penicillin G. Currently, 'Penicillin' is used as a generic term for antibiotics that contain the beta lactam unit in the chemical structure. For example, amoxicillin tablets may be labelled as 'a penicillin'. Other derivatives such as procaine benzylpenicillin (procaine penicillin), benzathine benzylpenicillin (benzathine penicillin), and phenoxymethylpenicillin (penicillin V) are also described as 'penicillins'. Procaine penicillin and benzathine penicillin have the same antibacterial activity as benzylpenicillin but act for a longer period of time.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penicillin

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Benzylpenicillin was the first form of penicillin
Currently penicillin is used for a variety of antibiotics
Penicillin G contains the beta lactam unit in its chemical structure
Procaine benzylpenicillin has the same chemical structure as benzathine penicillin
Modern antibiotics classified as penicillin have at least 1 similar structural chemical feature
questions.explanation:
1. The term penicillin was originally used for benzylpenicillin, however that does not mean that benzylpenicillin was the first form of penicillin. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. In the passage, around at least 4 antibiotics are listed as being labelled as penicillin or described as such, but we do not know that penicillin is an actual compound in these drugs (all we know from this passage is that it is a name used to label drugs). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We know penicillin G was originally called penicillin, however we do not know if ‘currently’ this is still the case, so we don’t know if it has the beta lactam unit in its chemical structure. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We know they share the beta lactam unit, but other than that we have no information on their similarities. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Currently, antibiotics classified as penicillin share the beta lactam unit in their chemical structure. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
According to the principle of conservation of mechanical energy, the mechanical energy of an isolated system remains constant in time, as long as the system is free of friction and other non-conservative forces. In any real situation, frictional forces and other non-conservative forces are present, but in many cases their effects on the system are so small that the principle of conservation of mechanical energy can be used as a fair approximation. Though energy cannot be created or destroyed in an isolated system, it can be converted to another form of energy.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_energy

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Theoretically, a system cannot have any friction
If a system has non-conservative forces, the mechanical energy of that system will remain constant
The principle of conservation of mechanical energy can be used whether friction is present or not
In a non-isolated system, energy can be created
Mechanical energy can be converted into another form of energy in an isolated system
questions.explanation:
1. According to the principle of conservation of mechanical energy, the mechanical energy of an isolated system remains constant in time, as long as the system is free of friction. Thus, in principle, a system can be free of friction. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. The system also needs to be free of friction, so if it only has non-conservative forces, we cannot guarantee that the mechanical energy of the system will remain constant. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. The principle of conservation of mechanical energy is used when friction is not present, however it can still be used when frictional forces are so small in effect. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. We cannot tell this based on the information provided. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. The passage states that energy can be converted into another form of energy in an isolated system, so we can infer that in an isolated system mechanical energy can be converted into another form. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Electrical energy is energy derived from electric potential energy or kinetic energy. When used loosely, electrical energy refers to energy that has been converted from electric potential energy. This energy is supplied by the combination of electric current and electric potential that is delivered by an electrical circuit (e.g., provided by an electric power utility). At the point that this electric potential energy has been converted to another type of energy, it ceases to be electric potential energy. Thus, all electrical energy is potential energy before it is delivered to the end-use. Once converted from potential energy, electrical energy can always be called another type of energy (heat, light, motion, etc.).
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrical_energy

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Electric potential energy always produces electrical energy
Electrical energy is mostly derived from electric potential energy
Once potential energy converts to another form of energy, it is no longer potential energy
Electrical energy cannot be called motion energy before it is converted from electric potential energy
Electric power utilities can be used to provide electric current and electric potential energy
questions.explanation:
1. We know that electric potential energy can be converted into electrical energy, however there is nothing to suggest that electric potential energy ONLY produces electrical energy. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. Electrical energy can also be derived from kinetic energy, however we do not know what proportion of electrical energy is derived from kinetic vs electric potential energy. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. There is nothing to suggest this as a general rule applying to potential energy. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Electrical energy can always be called another type of energy including motion energy, once converted from potential energy. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. The passage states that electric current and electric potential is delivered by an electrical circuit provided by an electrical power utility as one example. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Nuclear binding energy is the minimum energy that would be required to disassemble the nucleus of an atom into its component parts. These component parts are neutrons and protons, which are collectively in the presence of each other called nucleons. The binding energy is always a positive number, as we need to spend energy in moving these nucleons, attracted to each other by the strong nuclear force, away from each other.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_binding_energy

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Protons by themselves cannot be called nucleons
The consumption energy of something will be a negative number
Disassembling the nucleus of an atom requires a lot of energy
An atom’s nucleus can only be disassembled if enough nuclear binding energy is present or used
Electrons are not component parts of a nucleus
questions.explanation:
1. Nucleons are neutrons and protons in the presence of each other, so alone they cannot be called nucleons. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. Just because the binding energy is always a positive number does not mean the consumption energy must be a negative number. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We do not know if nuclear binding energy is a lot of energy or not. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Nuclear binding energy refers to the minimum energy required, not necessarily the energy itself that is used to disassemble the nucleus. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. The passage states that the component parts of the nucleus are neutrons and protons, so we can infer that electrons are not component parts of a nucleus. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Convective circulation allows one body to heat another, through an intermediate circulating fluid that carries energy from a boundary of one to a boundary of the other; the actual heat transfer is by conduction and radiation between the fluid and the respective bodies. Convective circulation, though spontaneous, does not necessarily and immediately occur simply because of some slight temperature difference; for it to occur in a given arrangement of systems, there is a threshold that must be crossed.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: If a hot iron touches a shirt, which then becomes hot, this is an example of convective circulation
If a cold metal stick becomes hot after it is contact with another hot metal stick, this is an example of convection
Convective circulation is instantaneous
Convective circulation does not always occur
Convective circulation requires a fluid to work
questions.explanation:
1. Convective circulation uses an intermediate fluid that carries energy from one boundary of a place to another, however this is not the case if a hot iron touches a shirt (which uses steam not liquid). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We only know what convective circulation is, not necessarily convection, however this example is not an example of convection anyway. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. Convective circulation is spontaneous, but does not necessarily and immediately occur. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. For convective circulation to occur in a given arrangement of systems, there is a threshold that must be crossed. If this is not crossed, then convective circulation will not occur (or so we can infer). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. Convective circulation uses an intermediate fluid that carries energy from one boundary of a body to another boundary of another body. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Heat capacity is a measurable physical quantity equal to the ratio of the heat added to an object to the resulting temperature change. The molar heat capacity is the heat capacity per unit amount (units: mole) of a pure substance, and the specific heat capacity, often called simply specific heat, is the heat capacity per unit mass of a material. Heat capacity is a physical property of a substance, which means that it depends on the state and properties of the substance under consideration.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: If the molar heat capacity of water is 4.18, the heat capacity per mole of water is also 4.18
The molar heat capacity of a pure substance can go by multiple names
The heat capacity of solid ice will be different to the heat capacity of liquid water
The specific heat capacity of a gaseous substance can be the same as that of a solid substance
Heat capacity cannot be calculated without a temperature change
questions.explanation:
1. Molar heat capacity is the same as the heat capacity per unit mole. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. The molar heat capacity and specific heat capacity are two different things (molar heat capacity is per mole, specific heat capacity is per unit mass, like grams). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. Heat capacity depends on the state and properties of the substance under consideration. Solid ice and liquid water have different states (liquid vs solid) and properties. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. There is no information to support this statement, and we know that heat capacity in general is dependent on the state and properties of the substances (so a gas might not have the same specific heat capacity as a solid substance). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Since heat capacity is equal to the ratio of the heat added to an object to the resulting temperature change, a temperature change must be involved in the calculations of heat capacity. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Matter in the solid state maintains a fixed volume and shape, with component particles (atoms, molecules or ions) close together and fixed into place. Matter in the liquid state maintains a fixed volume, but has a variable shape that adapts to fit its container. Its particles are still close together but move freely. Matter in the gaseous state has both variable volume and shape, adapting both to fit its container. Its particles are neither close together nor fixed in place.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_matter

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Matter in liquid and solid forms share at least one common physical property
Matter in gaseous state can fit into a 250cm3 and 300cm3 box
If matter in a solid state and matter in a liquid state were poured into the same box, they would maintain the same volume as each other
Particles in matter in the liquid state are close together
The reason matter in the solid state maintains a fixed volume is because its particles are close together
questions.explanation:
1. Matter in the solid and liquid state both maintain a fixed volume. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. Matter in a gaseous state has variable volume, and adapts to fit its container, so it would be able to fit both boxes. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. Matter in a solid state and liquid state have a fixed volume, but that does not mean that they will have the same volume as each other when put in the same box. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. In matter in the liquid state, its particles are still close together but move freely. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. We know that matter in the solid state has particular close together and has a fixed volume, but we do not know that this is the reason for the fixed volume (there could be any number of reasons that are not mentioned here). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
Like a gas, plasma does not have definite shape or volume. Unlike gases, plasmas are electrically conductive, produce magnetic fields and electric currents, and respond strongly to electromagnetic forces. Positively charged nuclei swim in a 'sea' of freely-moving disassociated electrons, similar to the way such charges exist in conductive metal, where this electron 'sea' allows matter in the plasma state to conduct electricity.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_matter

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Gases do not have a definite volume and are electrically non-conductive
Gases respond weakly to electromagnetic forces
A conductive metal has similar physical properties to plasma
A conductive metal can conduct electricity
A non-conductive substance cannot have a ‘sea’ of electrons
questions.explanation:
1. Gas is similar to plasma in that it does not have a definitive shape or volume (thus we know gas has a definitive volume), and unlike gases plasma are electrically conductive (which means gases are not electrically conductive). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. Unlike gases, plasmas are electrically conductive, produce magnetic fields and electric currents, and respond strongly to electromagnetic forces. We can infer that gases do not respond strongly to electromagnetic forces, but that does not mean they respond weakly (they could respond mildly for example). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We only know that conductive metal and plasma share the existence of charges, which is linked to conducting electricity – a physical property. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. We know the electron sea allows matter in the plasma state to conduct electricity, and since conductive metals share this property, we can infer that they are also electrically conductive. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. The ‘sea’ of electrons mentioned is described as enabling the electrical conductivity, so if a substance were to have this ‘sea’ of electrons they could have electrical conductivity, but that does not mean that non-conductive substances cannot have this (they could have this ‘sea’, but maybe something else disrupts the electrical conductivity for example, we don’t know for sure). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
Many governments require food manufacturers to label the energy content of their products, to help consumers control their energy intake. In the European Union, manufacturers of packaged food must label the nutritional energy of their products in both kilocalories and kilojoules, when required. In the United States, the equivalent mandatory labels display only 'Calories' (kilocalories), often as a substitute for the name of the quantity being measured, food energy; an additional kilojoules figure is optional and is rarely used.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_energy

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Food manufacturers label the energy content of their products because they want their consumers to regulate their energy intake
Packaged food manufacturers in countries outside the European Union are not required to label the nutritional energy intake of their products
Packaged food manufacturers in the United States are not required to label the nutritional energy of their products in kilojoules
The measurement of kilocalories is more popular than kilojoules
If food manufacturers did not label the energy content of their products, consumers would not be able to control their energy intake
questions.explanation:
1. The governments want to help consumers control their energy intake, but the food manufacturers are required to do so by the government (so we don’t know if they would do it to help consumers control their energy intake without it being mandatory etc). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We know that the United States required nutritional energy intake labels, and (a) we can infer that the United States is outside of the European Union since it does not follow the same rules as them, the (b) we have no information about what other countries are doing (or not doing). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. The United States requires the labelling of the calories/kilocalories, and kilojoules figures are “optional”. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. Just because kilocalories is used more than kilojoules in the United States does not make it more popular (in the European Union, both are used for example). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Although the labelling of energy content on food products was designed to help consumers control their energy intake, we have no information on whether it actually worked, or if this is the ONLY way consumers can regulate their energy intake. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
The amount of food energy associated with a particular food could be measured by completely burning only the dried food in a bomb calorimeter, a method known as direct calorimetry. However, the values given on food labels are not determined in this way. The reason for this is that direct calorimetry also burns the dietary fibre, and so does not allow for faecal losses; thus direct calorimetry would give systematic overestimates of the amount of fuel that actually enters the blood through digestion.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_energy

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Direct calorimetry involves a bomb calorimeter
The amount of food energy of a particular food cannot be measured in a bomb calorimeter if the food contains water
The values of food energy on food labels do not using bomb calorimeters
Dietary fibre does not provide energy when consumed/digested
If food labels were to use direct calorimetry to determine the energy of the food, they would be overestimating the energy content of the food
questions.explanation:
1. The method of completely burning only the dried food in a bomb calorimeter is known as direct calorimetry. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. The amount of food energy in a particular food can be measured by completely burning ONLY the dried food in a bomb calorimeter, so if the food had water in it, the measurements would not be accurate or the mechanism would not work etc, as it states that the food needs to be dried first. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. The values given on food labels are not determined “in this way” (ie. direct calorimetry using a bomb calorimeter), however, the issue with direct calorimetry is that the dietary fibre is also burned – we do not know whether bomb calorimeters are used in another method where the dietary fibre can be removed before burning etc (bomb calorimeters are the tool used in part of the method, not the entire method itself). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Since the burning of dietary fibres through direct calorimetry gives systematic overestimates for the amount of fuel that actually enters the blood via digestion, we can infer that dietary fibres do not produce any energy when digested or consumed in the body (hence when the food is burned using direct calorimetry, not in the body, an overestimate of the food energy is achieved because the dietary fibre is burned as well in direct calorimetry). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. Since direct calorimetry gives a systematic overestimate of the amount of fuel that actually enters the blood through digestion, food labels using direct calorimetry to get the energy content of the food would be overestimating the energy content of the food. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

questions.explanation:
1. “Students taking an online class have more flexibility in their schedules to take their classes at a time that works best for them”. This does not mean that flexibility is the reason students will take online classes, only that flexibility is a benefit of online classes. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We know that one difference between online and normal class is that the students are not face to face with the instructor, but there is nothing to say in the text that this is a disadvantage, only that it is a difference. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We do not know whether online students are able to cheat on tests or assignments based on their access to online sources. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Online classes have the advantage of students not needing to leave their house for a morning class, and so students who live in remote areas with no nearby educational institutions could benefit from not having to leave their remote home to go to school etc. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. Online classes can make understanding of the content difficult, especially when not able to get in quick contact with the instructor – although this does not mean that online students cannot contact their instructors at all (only that it makes learning difficult when they can’t). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
A national university is generally a university created or run by a national state but at the same time represents a state autonomic institution which functions as a completely independent body inside of the same state. Some national universities are closely associated with national cultural, religious or political aspirations, for instance the National University of Ireland, which formed partly from the Catholic University of Ireland which was created almost immediately and specifically in answer to the non-denominational universities which had been set up in Ireland in 1850.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: All national universities are run by a national state
The Catholic University of Ireland was created so that there would be a religious university in Ireland around 1850
The Catholic University of Ireland is currently known as the National University of Ireland
A national university does not necessarily need to be under the control of a national state
The National University of Ireland is likely to be affiliated with Catholicism
questions.explanation:
1. The text states that “disciplinary practices detract from learning, saying that they undermine students’ individual dignity and sense of self-worth – the latter occupying a more primary role in students’ hierarchy of needs”. Thus we can infer that a student’s sense of self-worth (the ‘latter’, which means the last, of the two characteristics), is more important than their individual dignity. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. Forms of discipline are imposed in the name of greater efficiency, but there is nothing to say that it works. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We have no information about whether teachers can be practitioners of critical pedagogy or not. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We do not know where learning content sits on the students’ hierarchy of needs. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Although practitioners of critical pedagogy maintain that such disciplinary measures have no positive effect on student learning, this is their ‘opinion’, so we cannot say as a general fact that disciplinary measures have absolutely no positive effect on student learning. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
There are several major exceptions on tuition fees. In many European countries, it is possible to study without tuition fees. Public universities in Nordic countries were entirely without tuition fees until around 2005. Denmark, Sweden and Finland then moved to put in place tuition fees for foreign students. Citizens of EU and EEA member states and citizens from Switzerland remain exempted from tuition fees, and the amounts of public grants granted to promising foreign students were increased to offset some of the impact.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: In 2003, public universities in Sweden had free tuition
After 2005, public universities in Finland only charged tuition fees for foreign students
If France is in the EU, French citizens can go to a public university in Denmark for free
Some excelling foreign students with good potential can attain public grants to mitigate some of the financial stress of tuition fees in some European countries
In non-European countries, people must pay tuition fees for public universities
questions.explanation:
1. We know a national university is created OR run by a national state, however we do not know whether all of them are run by national states, or if some are just created and not run by national states for example. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. The Catholic University of Ireland was created specifically in answer to the non-denominational (ie. non-religious in this context) universities which has been set up in Ireland in 1950. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. The National University of Ireland was formed partly from the Catholic University of Ireland, but not entirely. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. A national university represents a state autonomic institution which functions as a completely independent body inside of the same state. Thus, we can infer that these university may not always be under the control of the national state. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. Even though the National University of Ireland was formed partly from the Catholic University of Ireland, we cannot be sure whether the university is affiliated with Catholicism for sure (since it was only formed partly from the Catholic University of Ireland). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
Superficially, all governments have an official or ideal form. The United States is a constitutional republic, while the former Soviet Union was a socialist republic. However self-identification is not objective, and as Kopstein and Lichbach argue, defining regimes can be tricky. For example, Voltaire argued that 'the Holy Roman Empire is neither Holy, nor Roman, nor an Empire'.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: If a government of Country X can identify themselves as a constitutional republic, they are then a constitutional republic
The Holy Roman Empire was a form of government
Kopstein argues that one cannot truly define the form of a government
The ideal form of government in the former Soviet Union was a socialist republic
Voltaire and Lichbach are likely to agree on the difficulty in defining regimes
questions.explanation:
1. If Sweden ‘then’ moved to put in place tuition fees for foreign students after public universities went without tuition fees until 2005, in 2003 we can infer that Sweden’s public universities did not have tuition fees. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. Before 2005, Finland did not charge any tuition fees in public universities. After 2005, they charged for foreign students. Thus we can infer that non-foreign students were still not charged. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. Citizens of the EU remain exempted from tuition fees in Denmark. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. Amounts of public grants are granted to promising foreign students were increased to offset from of the impact (of charging them fees). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. We do not know what happens in non-European countries. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
Democracy is a system of government where the citizens exercise power by voting. In a direct democracy, the citizens as a whole form a governing body and vote directly on each issue. In a representative democracy the citizens elect representatives from among themselves. These representatives meet to form a governing body. In a constitutional democracy the powers of the majority are exercised within the framework of a representative democracy, but the constitution limits the majority and protects the minority, usually through the enjoyment by all of certain individual rights, e.g. freedom of speech, or freedom of association.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Most democracies currently in the world are not direct democracies
A representative democracy is more efficient that a direct democracy
In a direct democracy, everyone does not enjoy individual rights like freedom of speech
A minority would be more likely to prefer a constitutional democracy more than a majority
In a constitutional democracy, citizens can exercise power by voting
questions.explanation:
1. It states that self-identification is not objective, so just because a country claims to be something does not mean that they actually are. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We do not know that the Holy Roman Empire was a form of government, as the point that is being illustrated with it is that self-identification is not objective (we do not know whether governments are the same as regimes or empires). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. Kopstein argues that defining regimes can be tricky, not that one cannot truly define a form of government. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. The socialist republic could have been the official OR ideal form of the Soviet Union, we do not know which one, or if it was both. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Since the passage states that both Kopstein and Lichbach argue that definine regimes can be tricky, we can infer that they agree on this argument. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
A republic is a form of government in which the country is considered a 'public matter', not the private concern or property of the rulers, and where offices of states are subsequently directly or indirectly elected or appointed rather than inherited. The people, or some significant portion of them, have supreme control over the government and where offices of state are elected or chosen by elected people. A common simplified definition of a republic is a government where the head of state is not a monarch. Philosopher Montesquieu included both democracies, where all the people have a share in rule, and aristocracies or oligarchies, where only some of the people rule, as republican forms of government.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: A democracy is a form of republican government
A monarch cannot exist in a country where the government is a republic
Some of the population may not have control over the government in a republic
An office of state is not always elected by the people
Aristocracies are less democratic than republics
questions.explanation:
1. We have no information about the proportions of types of democracies in the world in the text. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We have no information about the efficiencies of each type of democracy. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We do not know this for sure as we have no information on it. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. In a constitutional democracy the majority is limited and the minority is protected, so a minority would most likely prefer a constitutional democracy more than a majority would. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. The powers of the majority are exercised within the framework of a representative democracy, which allows citizens to elect representatives to vote on issues on their behalf. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Hydroelectricity is the application of hydropower to generate electricity. It is the primary use of hydropower today. Hydroelectric power plants can include a reservoir (generally created by a dam) to exploit the energy of falling water, or can use the kinetic energy of water as in run-of-the-river hydroelectricity. Hydroelectric plants can vary in size from small community sized plants (micro hydro) to very large plants supplying power to a whole country. As of 2019, the five largest power stations in the world are conventional hydroelectric power stations with dams.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydropower

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Hydroelectricity can only be generated from hydropower
Energy generated from hydroelectric plants can be created from the energy of the movement of water
Conventional hydroelectric power stations are the only type of hydroelectric power stations that currently exist in the world
Conventional hydroelectric power stations are the most efficient type of hydroelectric power stations
Hydropower can be used for other activities other than producing hydroelectricity
questions.explanation:
1. Montesquieu included democracies as a form of republican government, but that doesn’t mean this is actually the case. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. A republic is classified as a government where the head of state is not a monarch – however a monarch can exist in a republican country, just not as the head of state. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. “The people, or some significant proportion of them, have supreme control over the government…”. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. An office of state can be elected, or chosen by elected people. Thus, an office of state can be chosen indirectly by the people (people vote for someone who then determines an office of state for example), but this means that an office of state does not always have to be elected by the people. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. We do not know which is more democratic between aristocracies or republics. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
In a windmill, the force of the water's movement drives the blades of a wheel or turbine, which in turn rotates an axle that drives the mill's other machinery. Water leaving the wheel or turbine is drained through a tail race, but this channel may also be the head race of yet another wheel, turbine or mill. The passage of water is controlled by sluice gates that allow maintenance and some measure of flood control; large mill complexes may have dozens of sluices controlling complicated interconnected races that feed multiple buildings and industrial processes.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watermill

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: The blades of a wheel in a windmill can only be turned by water movement
The same water used to drive one windmill’s wheel can also be used to drive another windmill’s wheel
Large mill complexes must have multiple sluice gates in order to operate at that scale
Water can only be drained through a tail race
Windmills can be at risk of flooding
questions.explanation:
1. Hydroelectricity can be generated from hydropower, but we do not know that this is the only way of generating hydroelectricity (if hydroelectricity is the primary use of hydropower, then we can infer that there must be other uses for hydropower ). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. If energy from hydroelectric plants is generated from exploiting the energy of falling water, then it stands that this energy can be derived from the movement of water. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. There is no information to suggest this. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We cannot assume that they are the most efficient type, even though the five largest power stations in the world are conventional power stations with dams (they could be the largest for another reason). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. If hydroelectricity is the primary use of hydropower, then we can infer that there must be other uses for hydropower (secondary, tertiary… etc). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
39. XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX 39
1. We know water movement turns the blades in the wheel, but we do not know that ONLY water can do this. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. If “this channel [of leaving water] may also be the head race of yet another wheel”, we can infer that the water leaving one wheel can be used to turn another windmill’s wheel. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. Large mill complexes MAY have dozens of sluices, but there is nothing to say that they MUST have multiple sluices. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Water can be drained through a tail race, but we don’t know if that is the ONLY way to drain water. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. If “the passage of water is controlled by sluice gates that allow maintenance and some measure of flood control”, we can infer that the need to have flood control means that these windmills are at risk of flooding. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Oil extraction is simply the removal of oil from the reservoir (oil pool). Oil is always recovered as a water-in-oil emulsion, and specialty chemicals called demulsifiers are used to separate the oil from water. Oil extraction is costly and sometimes environmentally damaging. Offshore exploration and extraction of oil disturbs the surrounding marine environment.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petroleum#Production (edited)

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Oil can only be removed from an oil pool through oil extraction
In order to remove oil from water, a demulsifier must be used
In some cases, oil extraction does not harm the environment
Oil does not need to be demulsified if the mixture does not contain water
If you did not want to harm or disturb marine life and nature, you would not do oil extractions in those locations
questions.explanation:
1. Oil extraction is the removal of oil from an oil pool, however we do not know that this is the ONLY way to remove oil from an oil pool. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We do not know if there is such thing as a demulsifier – as far as we know, speciality chemicals are used to demulsify oil, but we do not know if they are ‘demulsifiers’. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. If oil extraction is sometimes environmentally damaging, we know that at for at least some cases, oil extraction is not environmentally damaging (otherwise it would say oil extraction is always environmentally damaging). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. Oil is demulsified in order to separate the oil from the water, so if there is no water in the oil, then oil does not need to be demulsified. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. Oil extraction disturbs the surrounding marine environment, so if you wanted to avoid this, you would not do oil extractions in these places. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text: Scientists have warned us that climate change may involve many complications such as increased sea levels, increased ocean acidification and increased extreme temperatures. If the climate were completely stable, one might expect to see highs and lows each accounting for about 50 percent of the records set. Since the 1970s, however, record-setting daily high temperatures have become more common than record lows across the United States. The most recent decade had twice as many record highs as record lows. This is shown in the graph below.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: The highest percentage of record highs in any decade shown is higher than the lowest percentage of record lows in any decade shown
The average percentage of daily records in each decade shown is higher for record lows
The temperature has increased from 1950-2000 according to the graph
In the 2010s, the percentage of daily record highs will be more than double that of the record lows
This increase in percentage of daily record highs can be attributed to climate change according to the graph
questions.explanation:
1. In highest percentage of record highs was around 70% in 2000, which is higher than the percentage of record lows in value at around 55% in 1960. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. By observation, since there are no obvious outliers for both record lows and record highs, we can observe that 4/6 record high columns are over 50 with the other 2 just under, whereas for record lows, only 2/6 record low columns are over 50 with the rest being just or well below. Thus, the average value for record highs must be higher than record lows. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. This graph does not tell us the actual temperatures (only the number of record highs and lows). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We cannot extrapolate the data from this graph to 2010. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. We cannot attribute any external reasons for these trends in the graph without further information. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text: 200 students from Mountainvalley Primary School completed the ‘School Transport Survey’, which asked the students what method of transport they used in 2019 to come to school. Their answers are as follows:

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: More students travelled by car to school than those who used public transport
The number of students who only walked was more than the total number of kids who rode a bike to school
Bicycles were more popular than cars in 2019
In 2020, more students will prefer to walk than take public transport to school
5 students did not use a car, bicycle, walk or take public transport to school
questions.explanation:
1. Since 19 and 1 are shared by both Car and Public Transport, we can ignore them. Since 32 is 14 higher than 18, we can determine that more students must have travelled by car (in the diagram, 5 students are missing, however regardless of whether they go in Car/Bicycle or Public Transport/Walked spaces, more students in total would still travel by car because the difference between Car and Public Transport is 14, which is greater than 5). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. Only walked = 66. Only rode a bike = 47. Thus more only walked than only rode a bike to school. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. Bicycles = 47 + 12 + 1 = 60. Cars = 32 + 19 + 1 = 52. Thus, more rode bicycles than cars – however, we do not know if they were more popular or not beyond the school (maybe students were forced to ride a car). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We cannot extrapolate this data to 2020 since it is for 2019 only. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Although 5 students are missing from the diagram, we do not know where they go because there are multiple blank spaces including outside the Venn diagram. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
Air pollution has become a significant concern within the last 50 years as the negative health implications have become more widely observable. In 2000, NASA launched a study investigating CO2 emissions in California by consumption sector and within the transportation sector. The following two pie charts summarise the findings.
Source: https://www.giss.nasa.gov/meetings/pollution2002/summaryd.html

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: In America, transportation produced more CO2 emissions than any other sector
Gasoline fuelled transportation in California produced more CO2 emissions than the electric power and industrial sectors combined
Diesel fueled transportation produced more than double the CO2 emissions of the commercial sector in California
More people in California use CO2-producing fuels than non-CO2 producing fuels
CO2 emissions produced by the industrial sector account for less than 1/6th of the CO2 emissions produced by sectors in California
questions.explanation:
1. These statistics are for California only, so we cannot extrapolate them for America as a whole. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. Gasoline = 63%. Electric power + Industrial = 16 + 13 = 29%, which is less than 63%. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. Diesel = 14%. Commercial = 4%. Since double of 4% = 8%, which is still less than 14%, we can say that diesel transportation produced more than double the CO2 emissions of commercial sectors. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. We do not have any information about non-CO2 producing fuels. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Industrial = 13%. Since 1/6th is approximately equivalent to around 16.67%, we can say that CO2 emissions produced by the industrial sector are less than 1/6th of the total CO2 emissions by sector. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
The search for a longer lifespan continues as the World Health Organisation investigated the top 10 leading causes of death over an 11 year segment. Ischaemic heart disease, stroke, lower respiratory infections, chronic obstructive lung disease, diarrhoea, and HIV/AIDS have remained the top major killers during the past decade.
Source: https://www.who.int/gho/mortality_burden_disease/causes_death/2000_2011/en/

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: In 2000, tuberculosis caused more deaths than trachea, bronchus and lung cancers
Between the years 2000-2011, HIV/AIDS has stayed as the 6th highest leading cause of death
From 2000-2011, the number of annual road injuries in the world has increase
Lower respiratory infections caused more global deaths in 2011 than chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in 2000
For the majority of the causes shown on the graph, the number of annual deaths in 2000 were less than those in 2011
questions.explanation:
1. In 2000, tuberculosis was ranked at 8 whereas trachea, bronchus and lung cancers were ranked at 9 (meaning tuberculosis caused more deaths in 2000). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. In 2000, HIV/AIDS was rank 6, and in 2011, it was also rank 6. However, we do not know if it remained rank 6 for the years between 2000 and 2011. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We only have data from the number of deaths from road injuries, not that actual frequency of the road injuries themselves. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. If we compare the top bar from lower respiratory infections (2011) with the bottom bar of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (2000), we can see by observation that the top bar for lower respiratory infections is greater/longer. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. Of the 11 causes shown, only in 2 causes (lower respiratory infections, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) was the number of deaths in 2011 less than the number of deaths in 2000. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
The following Venn Diagram shows the favourite class subject for a sample of Year 7s at Glengordon High School.
Source: https://www.ck12.org/probability/venn-diagrams/lesson/Probability-Using-a-Venn-Diagram-and-Conditional-Probability-ALG-II/

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: In Glengordon High School there are 260 Year 7 students
More Year 7 students in the sample prefer Spanish than Math
Not all the Year 7 students sampled preferred Spanish, Chemistry or Math
Some of the Year 7 students sampled prefer English
Close to a quarter of the Year 7 students sampled who preferred both Math and Chemistry liked all of the 3 subjects shown in the graph
questions.explanation:
1. 70 + 3 + 17 + 5 + 15 + 60 + 85 + 5 = 260 students in Year 7. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. Spanish = 70 + 5 + 15 + 3 = 103. Math = 85 + 60 + 5 + 15 = 165. 165 is greater than 103 students. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. 5 students did not prefer any of the 3 subjects. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. We do not know if English was another subject on offer. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. 60 students liked Math and Chemistry, and if 260 students are in the sample, then 60/260 = 23% approximately, which is close to 25% (which is a quarter). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text: World War II, also known as the Second World War, was a global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945. The graphs below demonstrates the countries involved and their respective fatal casualties over the 6 year war. https://fathersforlife.org/hist/wwiicas.htm

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: More civilians died in World War II than military personnel
Not many civilians died in the USA because most of the war effort was in Europe
France had more than half the World War II casualties of Yugoslavia
The number of Polish military personnel casualties were more than the total casualties of Austria and the USA combined
Germany had just under 4 million civilian casualties in World War II
questions.explanation:
1. Given that the USSR had civilian casualties of close to 17 million people, and all the 11 countries in the second graph had far less than 1 million civilian casualties (which means altogether much less than 11 million), we can observe that overall, the civilian casualties were more than the military casualties in WWII. All the other countries in the top graph also had more civilian than military casualties except Japan. This statement is also not a generalisation because it states that these were all the countries involved (so these were all the casualties). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. We cannot determine the reason for the low civilian casualties in the USA based just off this information. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. France = close to 800,000, while Yugoslavia = around 1.8 million. Thus, we can say that France has less than half the casualties of Yugoslavia. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Polish military casualties = just under 1 million. USA + Austria military casualties = under 300,000 + 375,000 = under 675,000, which is still less than 1 million for Poland. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. By observation on the graph, we can see that the civilian part of the bar graph for Germany covers just under 4 million people. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Energy consumption and energy costs have been on the rise in Australia. In just the 6 months between July 2017 and January 2018, the annual residential electricity bills for average consumers increased between $110 and $316. Small businesses saw an increase of up to 28%. The following graphs demonstrate the median annual bill of Australians from their residential states, and their energy providers. Only some states of Australia are listed.
Source: https://electricitywizard.com.au/electricity/electricity-bill/average-electricity-bill/

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: In 2017, the median annual electric energy bill in NSW was higher than that of Victoria in 2018
More people use electricity in Australia than gas
More Victorians used gas than electricity in the years 2017-18
The median annual electricity bill in SA in 2018 was more than double the 2017 median annual gas bill in the NSW
Only one state shown uses the same main energy provider for both gas and electricity
questions.explanation:
1. Median electric NSW bill in 2017 = $1,200/yr. Median electric VIC bill in 2018 = just under $1,200/yr. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. Only some states are shown in the graph, so we cannot say for sure that electricity is used more than gas in Australia. The graph also shows the median bill, not usage. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. The graph shows the median bill, not how many people use gas or electricity etc. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Median electricity SA bill in 2018 = $2,000/yr. Median gas NSW bill in 2017 = $800/yr, which is less than half of $2,000/yr. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. Only the ACT uses Evoenergy for gas and electricity, as the other states shown in the graph use different providers. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text: The following graph shows the time per week spent by students on different activities – homework, sport and movies.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: The time spent on homework a week increases every year from Year 7 to Year 12
In Year 10, students are more likely to spend more time weekly on sport than movies
In Year 11, the time spent a week on homework, sport and movies is more disproportionate to the time spent a week on the same activities in Year 7
Students in Year 9 spent less than half the time spent on homework a week as is spent a week in Year 12
A student in Year 7 spends double the amount of time on homework that a Year 11 student spends a week on sport and movies combined
questions.explanation:
